fields.home_content:
Welcome to Ex Libris

**Ex Libris** is a personal bibliographic catalog and research tool designed to bring order to even the most sprawling private library. It organizes your collection across four interconnected record types: **Authors** — capture biographical details and known aliases. **Works** — represent the creative text itself (a novel, poem, or essay). **Volumes** — record the specific physical or digital edition on your shelf. **Collections** — group books by author, theme, or period. In many cases, a **work** and a **volume** may appear identical, but **Ex Libris** distinguishes between them to reflect the multiple manifestations of a single text — whether it’s different printings of *The Hobbit* (1968 vs. 2014) or the reappearance of Robert Frost’s “The Road Not Taken” in various poetry anthologies. See the "About" section for more on this site's design philosophy. Throughout the site, **volume (book)** titles appear italicized, while **work** titles are set in roman (normal) type. Thus, when referring to Dickens’ A Christmas Carol as a **work**, the title is normal; when referring to *A Christmas Carol* as a particular **volume**, it is italicized. All book cover images are stock images.
fields.about_content:
## What and Why  

In a world where there are dozens of free, well-designed library apps, why make my own? First, while there are some great apps out there (I, myself, have happily used Libib for years), no one app does everything I want and many do things I have no use for. I wanted something customized to my specs. For example, in addition to being a bibliophile, I am a collector, particularly of works by and about J.R.R. Tolkien. While most people are (justifiably) content with an app that tracks titles, authors, and basic bibliographic information, collectors have more specific wants. For example, for anyone with *The Hobbit* in their library, it's usually enough to have the cover as an identifying photo. However, the collector (and fellow collectors) usually want images of the dust jacket (front, back, spine, and flaps), title page, copyright page, images of the book without the dust jacket, as well as images showing integrity of the spine, page condition, specific characteristics (e.g. errata) in certain editions, etc. They want to be able to record a book's condition and, separately, the dust jacket's (if any) condition. They also want a way to track price, value, and disposition if a volume ever leaves their collection whether through sale, trade, or loss. This app allows me to do all of these things (well, the photo upload functionality is still under development).

In addition, I wanted a more robust bibliographic tool than is usually available in an app store. For example, I wanted something that allowed me to track various editions and appearances of works of literature in some structured way so, for example, instead of just tracking 11 individual editions of *The Silmarillion*, each as its own entity, I track the single work The Silmarillion, which exists independently of any specific format or edition, **and** the 11 individual volumes I own, all of the same work but distinctive in their own way. This is the basis for the **Work/Volume** distinction. Dickens' "A Christmas Carol" is a work. The *Oxford Illustrated Christmas Carol*, *A Christmas Carol* as found in a volume of Hazell Watson & Viney's Dickens collection, or Macmillan's pocket edition of *A Christmas Carol* are all **manifestations** of the work and the individual copies of these that I own are **items** or **volumes** or **books**. To illustrate the principal further, let's consider poetry. Poems are typically not books (epic poems and novels in verse aside), but are **works** in their own right. This system allows me to treat Robert Frost's "The Road Not Taken" as a single work **and** catalog the several individual volumes that contain the poem, like Frost collections, anthologies of American poets, or books of poems about indecisive friends. This distinction between **works** and **volumes** (and **manifestations**, but we won't go that deep into the weeds) is based on the FRBR (Functional Requirements for Bibliographic Records) philosophy, distinguishing between the intellectual entity or product (e.g. text) from physical items (e.g. books) containing that entity. It's the design standard underlying most actual library catalogs.

## Tech Nerd Stuff  

Technically, this was a fun site to develop. It was built using the Django web framework (a mature web framework written in Python). It retrieves book data from the Google Books api and uses fuzzy string matching to automatically associate books with known authors and works, greatly simplifying the process for adding new books. Django All-Auth handles all authentication functions and the site is styled, for the most part, using Bootstrap. Static page content is composed and managed in the site's admin dashboard using a markdown to html converter, eliminating the need to redeploy the project whenever static content changes. It uses (or will use) Python's Pillow library for image processing and management, automatically normalizing image formatting and minimizing storage requirements. In development, data is stored using SQLite; in production, Postgres.

fields.bio:
### Childhood John Ronald Reuel Tolkien was born on 3rd January 1892 in Bloemfontein, in the Orange Free State (now South Africa), to Arthur and Mabel Tolkien. His parents, both originally from Birmingham, had moved to South Africa so that Arthur could pursue his career in banking. When Tolkien was three years old, his mother took him and his younger brother Hilary to visit their family in England. The visit became permanent when his father died unexpectedly in South Africa. Mabel settled with her two young sons in Sarehole, a small village just outside Birmingham, which was later to inspire the Shire in Tolkien’s writings. ### School Tolkien won a scholarship to the prestigious King Edward VI School in Birmingham when he was eight years old and the family moved back to the city for the remainder of his school-days. He excelled in languages studying French, German, Latin and Greek and also taking an interest in Old English, Middle English and Gothic. Unfortunately his mother developed diabetes when he was twelve years old and her health began to deteriorate rapidly. Mabel was a recent convert to Catholicism and she arranged for Father Francis Morgan, a sympathetic Catholic priest, to become the boys’ guardian. She died within the year and although Ronald and his younger brother Hilary were now orphans, Father Francis maintained daily contact with them and gave them love and financial support for the rest of his life. ### T.C.B.S. At school Tolkien found a group of like-minded friends: Geoffrey Smith, Chris Wiseman and Rob Gilson were all precociously talented, in literature, mathematics and drawing respectively. They gathered in the school library illicitly brewing mugs of tea and when they were discovered and ejected, they decamped to Barrows department store where they could drink tea and continue their discussions uninterrupted. The Tea Club and Barrovian Society, or T.C.B.S. for short, was formed. These young men were drawn into close comradeship by a common desire to create something of beauty in the world but within a few years their dreams would be shattered by the war. ### University Tolkien applied to study Classics (Literae Humaniores, also known as Greats) at Oxford and on his second attempt he won a scholarship to Exeter College, Oxford, matriculating in 1911. After two years of fairly lax study, he was given permission to change from Classics to English, so that he could pursue his growing interest in Germanic philology, and more specifically Old Norse, Old English and Middle English. In the same year, 1913, he was reunited with Edith Bratt, a fellow orphan whom he had met in shared lodgings in Birmingham. Initially Tolkien’s guardian had tried to extinguish their youthful romance. Fearing that a relationship would distract Tolkien from his studies, he had banned any contact between them for three years. As soon as Tolkien reached his twenty-first birthday and the prohibition was lifted, he wrote to Edith and they became engaged within a week. ### World War 1 The renewal of their relationship gave him a new focus and he worked harder at his studies, graduating with a first class degree in June 1915. He immediately enlisted in the army, taking a commission in the Lancashire Fusiliers where he hoped to be placed in the same battalion as his school-friend, Geoffrey Smith. After training for a year in Staffordshire and Yorkshire, he qualified as a signalling officer. Aware of the approaching danger, he and Edith married in March 1916 and three months later he was sent to France for the start of the Somme offensive. He saw first-hand the horrors of trench warfare and the utter destruction of man, beast and landscape. Five months later he was sent back to England on a hospital ship suffering from trench fever. He was plagued by this recurring condition for the next two years and spent long periods in hospital, punctuated by stints of defensive duty on the east coast. It was during this time that he began to write down ‘The Lost Tales’, a series of heroic tales of the Elves from a far-distant time. These stories were the forerunner of The Silmarillion, his epic history of Elves and Men and Gods, which occupied him throughout his life and from which The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings eventually sprang. He may have been driven to write these stories down by the proximity of death. Certainly by the time the war ended Rob Gilson and Geoffrey Smith of the T.C.B.S. were dead, along with many of Tolkien’s university friends. Shortly before he died Geoffrey Smith had exhorted Tolkien to pursue the ideals they shared, ‘may you say the things I have tried to say long after I am not there to say them, if such be my lot.’ ### Early career With a wife and young son to support, he returned to Oxford at the end of the war and found employment working on the Oxford English Dictionary as a lexicographer. A year later in 1920, he gained his first academic position as Reader in English Language at the University of Leeds, becoming a professor there four years later. His Middle English Vocabulary, written for students using Kenneth Sisam’s Fourteenth Century Verse and Prose, was published in 1922 and his edition of the medieval romance, *Sir Gawain and the Green Knight*, co-edited with Eric Gordon, was published in 1925. In the same year he returned to Oxford as the Rawlinson and Bosworth Professor of Anglo-Saxon and a fellow of Pembroke College. For the next twenty years he taught Old English, Old Norse, Gothic and Germanic philology to undergraduates, supervised postgraduate research and pursued his own academic research. His British Academy lecture, ‘Beowulf: the monsters and the critics’ delivered in 1937, was a ground-breaking work which overturned decades of critical thought on this Old English epic poem. Another lecture, ‘On Fairy-stories’, delivered at St Andrew’s in 1939, set out to define fantasy and later came to be recognized as his justification for writing fantasy literature. ### The Inklings At Oxford Tolkien met C.S. Lewis, a colleague in the English Faculty. They soon discovered a shared love of northern myths and legends and would converse late into the night, ‘of the gods & giants & Asgard’. They were invited to attend meetings of an undergraduate club called the Inklings and when the club later foundered, they attached the name to a group of their own friends who met in pubs or college rooms to read aloud their works-in-progress, to drink, talk and debate. The Inklings, and C.S. Lewis in particular, would become crucial in encouraging Tolkien to finish his great work. ### *The Hobbit* In his spare time he continued to work on his legendarium; sketching out thousands of years of history, inventing languages, writing stories, plotting maps and painting landscapes. He also made up stories for his four children: John (born 1917), Michael (born 1920), Christopher (born 1924) and Priscilla (born 1929). Some of these stories were written down and illustrated, and one of them, *The Hobbit*, found its way to a publisher’s assistant who persuaded Tolkien to submit it for publication. It was published by George Allen & Unwin in 1937 with Tolkien’s own illustrations, maps and dust jacket design. The first print run sold out in three months and it became a perennial children’s classic. ### *The Lord of the Rings* The success of *The Hobbit* led his publisher, Stanley Unwin, to ask for more about hobbits. Tolkien submitted instead some of the unfinished prose and verse tales from 'The Silmarillion' but when these were roundly rejected, he sat down to write a Hobbit sequel. The story quickly outgrew its original form as a children’s story and burgeoned into an epic fantasy tale for adults. It took twelve years to complete, at the end of which Tolkien reflected, somewhat ruefully, that he had produced a ‘monster: an immensely long, complex, rather bitter, and very terrifying romance, quite unfit for children’. The work, *The Lord of the Rings*, was both a sequel to *The Hobbit* and to his unpublished legendarium, 'The Silmarillion'. In fact the works were so closely related in Tolkien’s mind that he decided *The Lord of the Rings* could only be published in conjunction with the, as yet unfinished, ‘Silmarillion’. His publisher baulked at the idea and lengthy negotiations with a rival publisher, Collins, also stalled. Three years later Tolkien wrote a chastened letter to George Allen & Unwin, declaring, ‘better something than nothing’. The huge size of the work and doubts as to its potential readership were major concerns but Rayner Unwin (son of Sir Stanley) was convinced of its merits and decided to publish it even if the firm suffered a financial loss. It appeared in three volumes between 1954 and 1955. Literary critics were divided over its merits but sales far outstripped both the publisher’s and the author’s expectations and it has continued to sell in astonishing numbers and to be translated into an ever-increasing number of languages. ### Later career In 1945, while still struggling to finish *The Lord of the Rings*, Tolkien was elected Merton Professor of English Language and Literature at Oxford. His academic focus now switched from Old to Middle English and he had to prepare an entirely new set of lectures and seminars for texts that he had not taught since 1925. In the same year he published a short allegorical story, 'Leaf, by Niggle', which reflected some of his own concerns that *The Lord of the Rings* would never be completed. A few years later he published another short story, the comic tale of 'Farmer Giles of Ham', illustrated by Pauline Baynes. He retired in 1959 having served as a professor at Oxford for thirty-four years. ### Retirement In retirement Tolkien hoped to complete ‘The Silmarillion’, which he had been working on for over forty years, and for which his publisher (and his readers) were now clamouring. However the success of *The Lord of the Rings* created its own workload and he was constantly called on to answer fan mail, give interviews and make appearances. He also had academic work to complete and his long-awaited edition of Ancrene Wisse, a medieval prose work, was finally published in 1962. In the same year he published a volume of poetry from Middle-earth, *The Adventures of Tom Bombadil*. A short fairy tale, *Smith of Wootton Major*, was published in 1967, described by Tolkien as ‘An old man’s book already weighted with the presage of “bereavement”‘, and in 1968 he collaborated with the composer Donald Swann to produce a songbook, *The Road Goes Ever On*. He and Edith moved from Oxford to Bournemouth in 1968, hoping that in relative seclusion he would be able to complete his life’s work. Edith’s health was already failing though and she died in November 1971 leaving Tolkien bereft after fifty-five years of marriage. He returned to Oxford to live in a flat owned by Merton College but the completion of *The Silmarillion* proved too great a task for him. He died on 2nd September 1973, aged eighty-one, while visiting friends in Bournemouth and is buried in Oxford alongside his beloved wife Edith. Their gravestone is marked with the additional names, Beren and Lúthien, whose love defeated the Dark Lord and overcame death itself in the First Age of Middle-earth.

Source: The Tolkien Estate

Mark Twain, born Samuel Langhorne Clemens on November 30, 1835, in Florida, Missouri, grew up along the banks of the Mississippi River in Hannibal — a setting that would later become immortalized in The Adventures of Tom Sawyer and Adventures of Huckleberry Finn. After the death of his father, young Sam left school early and apprenticed at a local print shop, where he discovered both his love of language and the power of satire. By his late teens he was traveling as a journeyman printer, absorbing stories, dialects, and characters that would later fuel his fiction.

In his twenties Clemens headed west and tried his hand at nearly everything: silver mining, journalism, and most famously steamboat piloting — the profession that gave him his pen name, “Mark Twain,” a riverboat term meaning two fathoms deep. He gained national attention with his 1865 short story “The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County,” which showcased his sharp humor and gift for the tall tale. Not long after, he published The Innocents Abroad, a travel book that cemented his reputation as one of America’s funniest and most observant writers.

Twain’s major novels — Tom Sawyer, Huckleberry Finn, The Prince and the Pauper, and A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur’s Court — blended biting social criticism with comic exuberance. Huckleberry Finn in particular is often hailed as the first great American novel, celebrated for its vernacular style and unflinching portrait of racism and moral growth. Twain’s mix of humor, realism, and moral clarity placed him at the center of American literary identity.

His later years were shadowed by financial trouble and personal tragedy. Failed investments forced him into exhausting lecture tours around the world, and he endured the deaths of several family members, including his beloved wife, Olivia, and two of their daughters. These losses deepened the darker, more cynical tone of some of his late writings, though his wit never fully dimmed.

Twain died on April 21, 1910, leaving behind a body of work that remains foundational to American literature. His voice — wry, humane, mischievous, and morally serious — continues to shape how Americans tell stories about themselves, their follies, and their hopes.

Umberto Eco (5 January 1932 – 19 February 2016) was an Italian medievalist, philosopher, semiotician, novelist, cultural critic, and political and social commentator. In English, he is best known for his popular 1980 novel The Name of the Rose, a historical mystery combining semiotics in fiction with biblical analysis, medieval studies and literary theory, as well as Foucault's Pendulum, his 1988 novel which touches on similar themes.

Eco wrote prolifically throughout his life, with his output including children's books, translations from French and English, in addition to a twice-monthly newspaper column "La Bustina di Minerva" (Minerva's Matchbook) in the magazine L'Espresso beginning in 1985, with his last column (a critical appraisal of the Romantic paintings of Francesco Hayez) appearing 27 January 2016. At the time of his death, he was an Emeritus professor at the University of Bologna, where he taught for much of his life. In the 21st century, he has continued to gain recognition for his 1995 essay "Ur-Fascism", where Eco lists fourteen general properties he believes comprise fascist ideologies.

George Eliot was the pen name of Mary Ann Evans, born on November 22, 1819, in Nuneaton, Warwickshire, England. She was the daughter of a land agent and received a solid, though unconventional, education for a woman of her time, developing a lifelong passion for literature, philosophy, and theology. After her mother’s death, Eliot ran her father’s household, but when he died in 1849, she moved to London and became a translator and editor, most notably working on The Westminster Review, a leading intellectual journal of the Victorian era.

Her decision to publish under a male pseudonym came from a desire to ensure her work would be taken seriously in a literary culture that often dismissed women’s writing as sentimental or domestic. Eliot’s fiction quickly established her as one of the foremost novelists of her age. Her major works—Adam Bede (1859), The Mill on the Floss (1860), Silas Marner (1861), Middlemarch (1871–72), and Daniel Deronda (1876)—are celebrated for their psychological depth, moral complexity, and social realism. Middlemarch in particular has been hailed as one of the greatest novels in the English language.

Eliot’s personal life was unconventional and controversial. She lived openly with George Henry Lewes, a married man who could not legally divorce his wife, in a partnership that scandalized Victorian society but was intellectually and emotionally fulfilling for both. Their relationship deeply influenced her writing and provided her with the stability to produce her most enduring works.

Mary Ann Evans died on December 22, 1880, in London. Though denied burial in Westminster Abbey due to her unorthodox life, she was later honored with a memorial stone there in 1980. Today, George Eliot is remembered not only as one of the greatest Victorian novelists but also as a pioneering woman who defied convention, shaped the modern psychological novel, and captured the moral struggles of ordinary lives with rare compassion and intellect.

Charles Dickens was born on February 7, 1812, in Portsmouth, England, the second of eight children in a family often teetering on the edge of financial ruin. His father, John Dickens, worked as a clerk in the Navy Pay Office but was chronically in debt—a flaw that would profoundly shape his son’s outlook. When Charles was twelve, his father was sent to debtors’ prison, and young Dickens was forced to leave school to work in a blacking factory, pasting labels on shoe polish bottles. The experience left deep emotional scars and later surfaced in his vivid depictions of child labor, poverty, and social injustice.

After a modest education, Dickens began his career as a law clerk and then a journalist, reporting on parliamentary debates and court proceedings. His first literary success came with Sketches by Boz (1836), a collection of humorous and sympathetic portraits of London life. That same year, he began serializing The Pickwick Papers, which became a cultural sensation and catapulted him to fame. Over the next three decades, he produced an extraordinary string of novels—Oliver Twist, Nicholas Nickleby, A Christmas Carol, David Copperfield, Bleak House, Great Expectations, and Our Mutual Friend, among others—that combined memorable characters, social critique, and narrative energy in a way unmatched in his era.

Dickens’s work reflected both his moral outrage at the injustices of Victorian society and his deep empathy for its victims. He wrote with reformist zeal about child exploitation, the failings of institutions, and the hypocrisy of the powerful, but always with humor and humanity. Beyond his novels, he was also a tireless public performer, editor, and philanthropist, known for his electrifying reading tours and his efforts to aid the poor and rehabilitate fallen women through charitable institutions.

Despite his fame, Dickens’s personal life was turbulent. His marriage to Catherine Hogarth deteriorated after two decades, and he separated from her amid a scandalous relationship with the much younger actress Ellen Ternan. He continued to write and perform until his health gave way. Dickens died on June 9, 1870, at his country home, Gad’s Hill Place, leaving his final novel, The Mystery of Edwin Drood, unfinished. He was buried in Westminster Abbey’s Poets’ Corner, fittingly among the literary greats whose ranks he had come to define.

Karen Lea Wynn Fonstad (April 18, 1945 – March 11, 2005) was the author of the popular Atlas of Middle-earth. In The Return of the Shadow, Christopher Tolkien credits Fonstad for noting a geographical inconsistency between The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings.

Karen Wynn was born and raised in Oklahoma, spending her later years in Wisconsin. She attended the University of Oklahoma, where she received a M.A. in Geography. Her speciality had been Cartography, and she would spend much of her life as a freelance cartographer. She has published several atlases of fantasy worlds, such as Arda, Pern, Krynn, Toril and The Land.

Source: [Tolkien Gateway](https://tolkiengateway.net/wiki/Karen_Wynn_Fonstad)

Joseph Loconte is an American historian, author, and cultural commentator best known for exploring the intersection of political thought, faith, and the moral imagination. Born in 1960, he grew up with a strong interest in history and public policy, eventually earning advanced degrees that led him into both academia and the world of policy analysis. Over the years he has become a distinctive voice in conversations about democracy, human dignity, and the role of religious belief in shaping the Western political tradition.

Loconte has taught at several institutions, including The King’s College in New York City and later Hillsdale College, where he serves as a senior fellow and professor of humanities. His scholarship often focuses on the intellectual roots of political liberty, drawing on figures such as John Locke, C. S. Lewis, and J. R. R. Tolkien. He has also written widely for publications like The Wall Street Journal, The New York Times, and National Review, developing a reputation for clear, historically grounded analysis.

His most widely read book, A Hobbit, a Wardrobe, and a Great War (2015), examines how Tolkien and Lewis were shaped by their World War I experiences and how their fiction carries a countercultural moral witness in an age of disillusionment. The book was praised for combining literary insight with historical depth, and it introduced many readers to Loconte’s larger argument that imaginative storytelling can be a bulwark against totalitarian and nihilistic worldviews. He has also produced documentary work expanding on this theme, including a multi-part film project about Tolkien’s wartime formation.

Beyond his academic writing, Loconte frequently engages in public discourse on foreign policy, religious freedom, and the moral responsibilities of democratic nations. His work tends to emphasize the fragility of liberty and the need for civic virtue, drawing lessons from history to warn against both utopian politics and cynical disengagement.

He continues to write, teach, and speak as an advocate for what he sees as the Western tradition’s spiritual and ethical foundations — a blend of historical realism, moral seriousness, and a genuine appreciation for the power of story to awaken conscience. If you want, I can also give you a short bio of Michael Ward, Tom Shippey, or other Lewis/Tolkien scholars.

Wayne Gordon Hammond (born 11 February, 1953) is a librarian known for his research and writings on the works of J.R.R. Tolkien. He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree with Honors as an English major at Baldwin-Wallace College in 1975 and Master of Arts in Library Science from the University of Michigan in 1976.[1] From 1976 onward he worked as Assistant Librarian at the Chapin Library of Rare Books at Williams College and became its director in 2015. Hammond retired in 2022.[2]

In 1994 Hammond married fellow Tolkien scholar Christina Scull and the two have since collaborated on several projects. He is a regular contributor to publications of the Mythopoeic Society.

Source: [Tolkien Gateway](https://tolkiengateway.net/wiki/Wayne_G._Hammond)

**Early life**  
Christopher Tolkien was named after his father's friend, Christopher Wiseman (he also sometimes used his confirmation name, "John" as seen on his initials of maps of The Lord of the Rings, "CJRT").

Born in Leeds and raised in Oxford, Christopher went to the Dragon School in Oxford and Oratory School in Caversham, Berkshire. He enjoyed watching stars with a telescope as well as a passion for railways. As early as age four and five, Christopher was concerned with the consistency of The Hobbit.

> [O]n one occasion I interrupted: 'Last time, you said Bilbo's front door was blue, and you said Thorin had a golden tassel on his hood, but you've just said that Bilbo's front door was green and that Thorin's hood was silver'; at which point my father muttered 'Damn the boy,' and then 'strode across the room' to his desk to make a note.   
    --Christopher Tolkien, foreword to The Hobbit

Christopher proved invaluable in correcting The Hobbit after its publication and was paid twopence a correction.

In 1937 he was with his elder brother Michael at The Oratory School. However, due to a heart ailment he was forced to stay at home and work with a private tutor. After spending a year with heart-specialists, on the turn of 1939, Christopher wanted to go to school.

**Young adulthood**  
In July of 1943 he entered the Royal Air Force and in November of that year he went to South Africa to train as a pilot. His absence did not however slow his contributions to his father's works as his father continually sent him parts of The Lord of the Rings to go over. In 1945 he returned to England and was stationed in Shropshire and later that year he returned to Oxford.

On October 9, 1945 his father informed him that the Inklings wished to consider him a permanent member. The task of reading The Lord of the Rings to the Inklings was passed on to Christopher and it was generally agreed that he was a better reader than his father.

In 1954-55 Christopher was delegated the re-drawing of his father's Lord of the Rings maps for publication.

**Adulthood**  
In 1946 Christopher returned to Trinity College to resume his studies and reading English. For a while his tutor was C.S. Lewis. His thesis was a translation of The Saga of King Heidrek the Wise and he received his B.A. in 1949. Christopher also became a lecturer in Old and Middle English as well as Old Icelandic at Oxford. He worked as an editor on Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, the Pardoner's Tale, and the Nun's Priest's Tale. From 1963 to 1975 he was a Fellow of New College, Oxford but resigned when he began to devote his time to his father's literary affairs, and soon afterward moved with his family to southern France.

**After his father's death**  
In J.R.R. Tolkien's last will and testament, Christopher was appointed literary executor and granted "full power to publish, edit, alter, rewrite, or complete any work of [his father's] which may be unpublished at [his] death or to destroy the whole or any part or parts of any such unpublished works". He embarked on the task of organizing the masses of his father's notes for subsequent publication; something he would continue to do for the remainder of his life. Much of the material was handwritten, frequently a fair draft was written over a half-erased first draft, and names of characters routinely changed between the beginning and end of the same draft. Deciphering this was an arduous task, and perhaps only someone with personal experience of J.R.R. and the evolution of his stories could have made any sense of it; even so, Christopher has admitted to having to occasionally guess at what his father intended.

With the help of Guy Gavriel Kay he managed to compile The Silmarillion in only four years. During this time, he also edited his father's translations of Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, and Sir Orfeo. He also worked on the Nomenclature of The Lord of the Rings, which was first published in 1975 as Guide to the Names in The Lord of the Rings in A Tolkien Compass.

Christopher spent the years after continuing to study his father's works and taking the responsibilities of the Tolkien Estate. He recorded portions of The Silmarillion in 1977 and 1978 which was issued by Caedmon Records, New York. In 1979 he wrote about his father's illustrations and drawings for their publication in Tolkien calendars and Pictures by J.R.R. Tolkien. Through 1980 and 1983 Christopher edited Unfinished Tales, The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien, The Monsters and the Critics and Other Essays, and The Book of Lost Tales Part One which was the first volume in his twelve volume series of The History of Middle-earth, the last of which was published in 1996. In 1998 he edited a new edition of Tree and Leaf including the poem Mythopoeia. In 2007, he edited The Children of Húrin, the first of the so called Great Tales of Middle-earth. His last publications were the editing of Beowulf: A Translation and Commentary (2014), Beren and Lúthien (2017) and The Fall of Gondolin (2018).

In 2016, Christopher Tolkien was awarded the Bodley Medal, the Bodleian Libraries' highest honour, for his "editorial work on his father's manuscripts" and his "academic career at the University of Oxford".

In August 2017, Christopher Tolkien resigned from his appointment as director of the Tolkien Estate.

He died on 16 January, 2020 in Draguignan, France.  

Source: [Tolkien Gateway](https://tolkiengateway.net/wiki/Christopher_Tolkien)

William Butler Yeats was born June 13, 1865, in Sandymount, County Dublin, into a family of artists and intellectuals. His father, John Butler Yeats, was a portrait painter, and the household atmosphere was steeped in creativity, political discussion, and Irish folklore. Young Yeats spent part of his childhood in Sligo, whose landscapes and stories would later become central to his poetic mythology. Early on he embraced poetry, mysticism, and nationalism, shaping the trajectory of his long literary life.

In the 1890s Yeats became a leading figure in the Irish Literary Revival, working alongside Lady Gregory, Douglas Hyde, and others to rekindle Irish cultural identity. His unrequited love for Maud Gonne — political activist, actress, and muse — fueled some of his most passionate early verse. During this period he also turned toward the occult, joining the Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn, a fascination that profoundly influenced his symbolism and cosmology.

Yeats was not only a poet but also a dramatist and co-founder of the Abbey Theatre in Dublin, believing that a national literature required a national stage. His early poetry is dreamlike and romantic, but as he aged his style sharpened — becoming more austere, forceful, and modernist. Collections such as In the Seven Woods, The Wild Swans at Coole, and The Tower mark that evolution, culminating in some of the most iconic poems of the 20th century, including “The Second Coming,” “Easter 1916,” and “Sailing to Byzantium.”

In 1923 Yeats received the Nobel Prize in Literature, praised for both his lyrical mastery and his role in revitalizing Irish letters. His later years were marked by continued political engagement, complex personal entanglements, and an increasingly philosophical poetry that wrestled with aging, history, violence, and the cyclical nature of civilizations. Even in his seventies he produced work of startling vitality and bite.

Yeats died on January 28, 1939, in Roquebrune-Cap-Martin, France. His body was reinterred in Drumcliffe, County Sligo, in 1948, beneath the epitaph he famously wrote for himself: “Cast a cold eye / On life, on death. / Horseman, pass by!” His legacy endures as one of the pillars of modern poetry — mystical, political, visionary, and deeply Irish.

Katharine Tynan (sometimes publishing as Katharine Tynan Hinkson after her marriage) was an Irish poet and novelist born on January 23, 1861, in Clondalkin, County Dublin. She was a major voice in the late-19th-century Irish Literary Revival, a movement that also included W. B. Yeats, Lady Gregory, and Douglas Hyde. Tynan was close friends with Yeats in their young writing years; he credited her influence and hospitality at her family home, Whitehall, with shaping his early career. Their correspondence shows her as both mentor and peer — someone Yeats genuinely admired.

Her poetry is characteristically lyrical, devotional, and rooted in Catholic spirituality and Irish landscape. She wrote prolifically: dozens of poetry collections, more than 100 novels, essays, memoirs, and countless articles. While she’s not widely read today, in her time she was extremely popular, especially for her sentimental novels and war poetry during World War I. Her writing often blended domestic themes, religious feeling, and a quietly nationalistic love for Ireland.

In 1893 she married Henry Hinkson, a barrister and writer, moved to England for a time, and published under the name Katharine Tynan Hinkson. After his death, she eventually returned to Ireland. Her memoirs — including Memories (1913) and The Middle Years (1917) — offer vivid portraits of literary Dublin and London, and they’re some of the best sources for firsthand glimpses into the younger Yeats.

Tynan died in 1931, leaving behind a vast body of work that scholars of Irish literature still revisit, though she remains more of a “writer’s writer” today — someone known to specialists, Yeats devotees, and readers of the Irish Revival but undeservedly obscure to the general reading public.

Colin Duriez (19 July 1947 – 1 November 2025) was an English writer on fantasy, especially that of the Inklings literary group centred around the Christian authors C. S. Lewis and J. R. R. Tolkien.

**Life and works**  
Colin Duriez was born in Derbyshire on 19 July 1947. He moved to Leicester in 1983 to work with a small publisher, IVP, as a commissioning editor. He took various teaching and editing jobs, and in 2002 he started his own business in Keswick, Cumbria, InWriting, devoted to writing, editorial services, and book acquisition for publishers.

Duriez won the Clyde S. Kilby Award in 1994 for his research on the Inklings, the literary group that included J. R. R. Tolkien and C. S. Lewis. He has been described as "the most useful scholar writing on Lewis today." He published many books on Christian literary figures, and spoke to literary, academic and professional groups. His television documentaries include A Quest for Meaning – Myth, Imagination & Faith in the Literature of J.R.R. Tolkien & C.S. Lewis.

Duriez died from complications of Alzheimer's disease on 1 November 2025, at the age of 78. At the time of his death, Duriez lived in Wallingford, Oxfordshire with wife and fellow author Cindy Zudys, having previously lived in Keswick, Cumbria.

Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, born February 27, 1807, in Portland, Maine (then part of Massachusetts), became one of the most celebrated American poets of the 19th century. Raised in an educated New England family, he showed early literary promise and published his first poem at 13. Longfellow attended Bowdoin College, where he was a classmate of Nathaniel Hawthorne, beginning a lifelong friendship that would situate him within the emerging American literary tradition.

After graduation, Longfellow embarked on European study and later returned to Bowdoin as a professor of modern languages before joining Harvard’s faculty. These years shaped his cosmopolitan style: he absorbed European romanticism, translated works from multiple languages, and sought to create poetry that could stand shoulder-to-shoulder with European counterparts. His early collections, such as Voices of the Night and Ballads and Other Poems, helped establish his reputation as a polished, musical, and emotionally accessible poet.

Longfellow found massive popular success with longer narrative works, including Evangeline (1847), The Song of Hiawatha (1855), and The Courtship of Miles Standish (1858). These poems blended American history, folklore, and landscape in a way that resonated with a nation hungry for its own cultural mythology. Though later critics sometimes dismissed him as overly sentimental, his craftsmanship and cultural influence were undeniable; he became the first American poet honored with a bust in Westminster Abbey’s Poets’ Corner.

His personal life, however, was marked by profound tragedy. Longfellow lost his first wife to miscarriage complications and his second wife, Fanny Appleton, to a horrific household fire, after which he grew the iconic beard that hid his own burns. These losses deepened his later poetry, infusing it with sorrow, faith, and a belief in the endurance of moral beauty — seen powerfully in poems like “Christmas Bells,” which later became the carol I Heard the Bells on Christmas Day.

Longfellow died in 1882, leaving behind a body of work that shaped the American poetic imagination for generations. Though tastes have shifted, his influence endures in the rhythms and stories that helped define American poetry at its formative moment.

**Humphrey William Bouverie Carpenter** (29 April 1946 – 4 January 2005) was an English biographer, writer, and radio broadcaster. He is known especially for his biographies of J. R. R. Tolkien and other members of the literary society the Inklings. He won a Mythopoeic Award for his book The Inklings in 1982.

## Early life
Carpenter was born in the city of Oxford, England. His father was Harry Carpenter, Bishop of Oxford. His mother was Urith Monica Trevelyan, who had training in the Fröbel teaching method.[2] As a child, he lived in the Warden's Lodgings at Keble College, Oxford, where his father served as warden until his appointment as Bishop of Oxford. He was educated at the Dragon School, Oxford and Marlborough College. He returned to Oxford to read English at Keble College.[citation needed]

## Broadcasting
Carpenter began his broadcasting career at BBC Radio Oxford as a presenter and producer where he met Mari Prichard (whose father was Caradog Prichard, the Welsh novelist and poet); they married in 1973.[2][3] They jointly produced A Thames Companion in 1975. He played a role in launching Radio 3's arts discussion programme Night Waves and acted as a regular presenter of other programmes on the network including Radio 3's afternoon drivetime programme In Tune and, until it was discontinued, its Sunday request programme Listeners' Choice. Until his death, he presented the BBC Radio 4 biography series Great Lives recorded in Bristol. The last edition recorded before his death featured an interview with the singer Eddi Reader about the poet Robert Burns, the major focus of her creative work. BBC Radio 4 broadcast this programme on New Year's Eve, 2004.

## Jazz music and children's drama
Carpenter was an amateur jazz musician who played the piano, the saxophone, and the double-bass, the last instrument professionally in a dance band in the 1970s. In 1983, he formed a 1930s style jazz band, Vile Bodies, which for many years enjoyed a residency at the Ritz Hotel in London. He also founded the Mushy Pea Theatre Group, a children's drama group based in Oxford, which premiered his Mr Majeika: The Musical in 1991 and Babes, a musical about Hollywood child stars.

## Children's books
His Mr Majeika series of children's books were adapted for television. The Joshers: Or London to Birmingham with Albert and Victoria (1977) is a children's adventure book, similar in style to The Railway Children and based on the adventure of taking a working narrowboat up the Grand Union Canal from London to Birmingham.

## Non-fiction works
His biographies included J. R. R. Tolkien: A Biography (1977; also editing of The Letters of J. R. R. Tolkien), The Inklings: CS Lewis, JRR Tolkien, Charles Williams and their Friends (1978; winner of the 1978 Somerset Maugham Award), W. H. Auden (1981), Ezra Pound (1988; winner of the Duff Cooper Memorial Prize), Evelyn Waugh (1989), Benjamin Britten (1992), Robert Runcie (1997), Dennis Potter, and Spike Milligan (2004). He authored Geniuses Together: American Writers in Paris in the 1920s (1987); his last book was The Seven Lives of John Murray (2008) about John Murray and the publishing house of Albemarle Street, was published posthumously.

He wrote histories of BBC Radio 3, the British satire boom of the 1960s, Angry Young Men: A Literary Comedy of the 1950s (2002), and a centennial history of the Oxford University Dramatic Society in 1985. His encyclopaedic work, The Oxford Companion to Children's Literature (1984), written jointly with his wife, Mari Prichard, has become a standard reference source.

## Death
Humphrey Carpenter died in 2005 of heart failure, compounded by the Parkinson's disease from which he had suffered for several years. He was buried in Wolvercote Cemetery in Oxford, also the final resting place of J. R. R. Tolkien.[4] A commemorative stained-glass window was installed in St Margaret's Institute, Polstead Road, honouring Carpenter's many accomplishments.[3]

Brian Sibley (born 14 July 1949) is an English author, broadcaster and screenwriter. He is author of over 100 hours of radio drama and has written and presented hundreds of radio documentaries, features and weekly programmes.

Born in London, he grew up and was educated in Chislehurst, Kent.

In 1981, he co-wrote BBC Radio 4's adaptation of Tolkien's The Lord of the Rings with Michael Bakewell. Sibley subsequently wrote The Lord of the Rings: The Making of the Movie Trilogy and other books accompanying The Lord of the Rings trilogy, including a biography of Jackson. He reprised this role a decade later by writing three companion books for The Hobbit trilogy.

He is also the author of a series of map books starting with The Map of Tolkien's Middle-earth, as well as the editor of book The Fall of Númenor.

James Edward Anthony "Tony" Tyler (October 31, 1943 – October 28, 2006), a British writer, was the author of The Tolkien Companion and its revisions. His main area of work, however, was articles on modern music, and also articles for several computer magazines. As a curiosity, Tyler was the godfather of James Bond-actor Daniel Craig.  

Source: [Tolkien Gateway](https://tolkiengateway.net/wiki/J.E.A._Tyler)

Dante was an Italian poet and moral philosopher best known for the epic poem The Divine Comedy, which comprises sections representing the three tiers of the Christian afterlife: purgatory, heaven and hell. This poem, a great work of medieval literature and considered the greatest work of literature composed in Italian, is a philosophical Christian vision of mankind’s eternal fate. Dante is seen as the father of modern Italian, and his works have flourished before his 1321 death.

﻿**Quick Facts**  
﻿FULL NAME: ﻿Dante Alighieri
﻿BORN: May 21, 1265
﻿DIED: September 13, 1321
﻿BIRTHPLACE: Florence, Italy
﻿SPOUSE: Gemma Donati (circa 1285-1321)
﻿ASTROLOGICAL SIGN: Gemini﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿

**Early Years**  
Dante Alighieri was born May 21, 1265, in Florence, Italy, to a family with a history of involvement in the complex Florentine political scene, and this setting would become a feature in his Inferno years later. Dante’s mother died only a few years after his birth, and when Dante was around 12 years old, it was arranged that he would marry Gemma Donati, the daughter of a family friend. Around 1285, the pair married, but Dante was in love with another woman—Beatrice Portinari, who would be a huge influence on Dante and whose character would form the backbone of Dante’s Divine Comedy.

Dante met Beatrice when she was only nine years old, and he had apparently experienced love at first sight. The pair were acquainted for years, but Dante’s love for Beatrice was “courtly” (which could be called an expression of love and admiration, usually from afar) and unrequited. Beatrice died unexpectedly in 1290, and five years later Dante published Vita Nuova (The New Life), which details his tragic love for Beatrice. Beyond being Dante’s first book of verse, The New Life is notable in that it was written in Italian, whereas most other works of the time appeared in Latin.

Around the time of Beatrice’s death, Dante began to immerse himself in the study of philosophy and the machinations of the Florentine political scene. Florence was then a tumultuous city, with factions representing the papacy and the empire continually at odds, and Dante held a number of important public posts. In 1302, however, he fell out of favor and was exiled for life by the leaders of the Black Guelphs (among them, Corso Donati, a distant relative of Dante’s wife), the political faction in power at the time and who were in league with Pope Boniface VIII. (The pope, as well as countless other figures from Florentine politics, finds a place in the hell that Dante creates in Inferno—and an extremely unpleasant one.) Dante may have been driven out of Florence, but this would be the beginning of his most productive artistic period.

**Exile**  
In his exile, Dante traveled and wrote, conceiving The Divine Comedy, and he withdrew from all political activities. In 1304, he seems to have gone to Bologna, where he began his Latin treatise "De Vulgari Eloquentia" (“The Eloquent Vernacular”), in which he urged that courtly Italian, used for amatory writing, be enriched with aspects of every spoken dialect in order to establish Italian as a serious literary language. The created language would be one way to attempt to unify the divided Italian territories. The work was left unfinished, but it has been influential nonetheless.

In March 1306, Florentine exiles were expelled from Bologna, and by August, Dante ended up in Padua, but from this point, Dante’s whereabouts are not known for sure for a few years. Reports place him in Paris at times between 1307 and 1309, but his visit to the city cannot be verified.

In 1308, Henry of Luxembourg was elected emperor as Henry VII. Full of optimism about the changes this election could bring to Italy (in effect, Henry VII could, at last, restore peace from his imperial throne while at the same time subordinate his spirituality to religious authority), Dante wrote his famous work on the monarchy, De Monarchia, in three books, in which he claims that the authority of the emperor is not dependent on the pope but descends upon him directly from God. However, Henry VII’s popularity faded quickly, and his enemies had gathered strength, threatening his ascension to the throne. These enemies, as Dante saw it, were members of the Florentine government, so Dante wrote a diatribe against them and was promptly included on a list of those permanently banned from the city. Around this time, he began writing his most famous work, The Divine Comedy.

**'The Divine Comedy'**  
In the spring of 1312, Dante seemed to have gone with the other exiles to meet up with the new emperor at Pisa (Henry’s rise was sustained, and he was named Holy Roman Emperor in 1312), but again, his exact whereabouts during this period are uncertain. By 1314, however, Dante had completed the Inferno, the segment of The Divine Comedy set in hell, and in 1317 he settled at Ravenna and there completed The Divine Comedy (soon before his death in 1321).

The Divine Comedy is an allegory of human life presented as a visionary trip through the Christian afterlife, written as a warning to a corrupt society to steer itself to the path of righteousness: "to remove those living in this life from the state of misery, and lead them to the state of felicity." The poem is written in the first person (from the poet’s perspective) and follows Dante's journey through the three Christian realms of the dead: hell, purgatory and finally heaven. The Roman poet Virgil guides Dante through hell (Inferno) and purgatory (Purgatorio), while Beatrice guides him through heaven (Paradiso). The journey lasts from the night before Good Friday to the Wednesday after Easter in the spring of 1300 (placing it before Dante’s factual exile from Florence, which looms throughout the Inferno and serves as an undercurrent to the poet’s journey).

The structure of the three realms of the afterlife follows a common pattern of nine stages plus an additional, and paramount, tenth: nine circles of hell, followed by Lucifer’s level at the bottom; nine rings of purgatory, with the Garden of Eden at its peak; and the nine celestial bodies of heaven, followed by the empyrean (the highest stage of heaven, where God resides).

The poem is composed of 100 cantos, written in the measure known as terza rima (thus the divine number 3 appears in each part of the poem), which Dante modified from its popular form so that it might be regarded as his own invention.

Virgil guides Dante through hell and a phenomenal array of sinners in their various states, and Dante and Virgil stop along the way to speak with various characters. Each circle of hell is reserved for those who have committed specific sins, and Dante spares no artistic expense at creating the punishing landscape. For instance, in the ninth circle (reserved for those guilty of treachery), occupants are buried in ice up to their chins, chew on each other and are beyond redemption, damned eternally to their new fate. In the final circle, there is no one left to talk to as Satan is buried to the waist in ice, weeping from his six eyes and chewing Judas, Cassius and Brutus, the three greatest traitors in history, by Dante’s accounting, and the duo moves on to purgatory.

In the Purgatorio, Virgil leads Dante in a long climb up the Mount of Purgatory, through seven levels of suffering and spiritual growth (an allegory for the seven deadly sins), before reaching the earthly paradise at the top. The poet’s journey here represents the Christian life, in which Dante must learn to reject the earthly paradise he sees for the heavenly one that awaits.

Beatrice, representing divine enlightenment, leads Dante through the Paradiso, up through the nine levels of the heavens (represented as various celestial spheres) to true paradise: the empyrean, where God resides. Along the way, Dante encounters those who on earth were giants of intellectualism, faith, justice and love, such as Thomas Aquinas, King Solomon and Dante’s own great-great-grandfather. In the final sphere, Dante comes face to face with God himself, who is represented as three concentric circles, which in turn represent the Father, Son and Holy Spirit. The journey ends here with true heroic and spiritual fulfillment.

**Legacy**  
Dante died on September 13, 1321, in Ravenna, Italy. His Divine Comedy has flourished for more than 650 years and has been considered a major work since Giovanni Boccaccio wrote a biography of Dante in 1373. By 1400, at least 12 commentaries had already been written on the poem’s meaning and significance. The work is a major part of the Western canon, and T.S. Eliot, who was greatly influenced by Dante, put Dante in a class with only one other poet of the modern world, Shakespeare, saying that they ”divide the modern world between them. There is no third.”  

**Source**
[Biography.com](https://www.biblio.com/authors?srsltid=AfmBOooFOcBqwy0XcLvknX4qTipaHPgqyUHW-27T_Ax_2LXFmGlyrYTP)

John Irving, born March 2, 1942, in Exeter, New Hampshire, grew up in a household marked by silence around the identity of his biological father — a theme that would echo through much of his fiction. He attended the prestigious Phillips Exeter Academy, where he struggled with dyslexia but found refuge in wrestling, a sport that became both discipline and metaphor throughout his life and work. Wrestling’s rigor shaped his writing habits: slow, methodical, revision-heavy.

Irving’s literary breakthrough came with The World According to Garp (1978), a darkly comic and emotionally charged novel that earned him widespread acclaim and firmly established his signature blend of eccentric characters, sexual politics, tragedy, and humor. Over the next decades he produced a string of major works — The Hotel New Hampshire, The Cider House Rules, and A Prayer for Owen Meany among them — each notable for elaborate plotting, moral seriousness, and a style that manages to be both tender and unsentimental.

He also became deeply involved in bringing his stories to the screen. Irving adapted The Cider House Rules for film, winning the Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay in 2000. His relationship with Hollywood has always been ambivalent, though — protective of his novels yet fascinated by the craft of adaptation, he often approaches screenwriting as a way to re-interpret rather than merely compress his books.

In later years Irving’s work continued to explore themes that have defined his career: the search for identity, the wounds of childhood, sexuality and gender, and the ways love and loss shape the moral imagination. He remains a meticulous, old-school novelist who drafts by hand, rewrites extensively, and treats storytelling as a long, muscular discipline. His most devoted readers tend to appreciate exactly that — the sense that every Irving novel feels built, not dashed off, by someone who believes deeply in the novel as an art form.

Dave Grohl, born January 14, 1969, in Warren, Ohio, grew up shuttling between suburbs in Ohio and Virginia before settling in Springfield, VA. A self-taught drummer, he ditched formal lessons early, deciding instead to play along to records by Led Zeppelin, Black Flag, and The Beatles. By his teenage years he was immersed in the D.C. punk scene, performing with the hardcore band Scream. That period shaped both his musical instincts and his famously unpretentious ethos: loud, earnest, no nonsense.

His trajectory changed in 1990 when he joined Nirvana after Scream dissolved. Grohl’s powerfully economical drumming became a defining part of Nevermind’s sound, helping propel the band—and the Seattle scene—into global prominence. Though he was the “new kid” in a trio dominated by Kurt Cobain’s songwriting, Grohl quietly wrote and recorded his own material on the side, unsure if it would ever see daylight. Cobain’s death in 1994 ended Nirvana and left Grohl confronting both grief and the question of what came next.

What came next was a reinvention. Grohl entered a studio alone, recorded every instrument and vocal himself, and released the result under the name Foo Fighters, partly as a shield against expectations. The debut snowballed into a full band, and over the next decades Foo Fighters became one of rock’s most enduring acts—balancing stadium-scale anthems with Grohl’s affable, blue-collar presence. Albums like The Colour and the Shape, There Is Nothing Left to Lose, and Wasting Light cemented his place as one of the most reliable songwriters in modern rock.

Beyond Foo Fighters, Grohl carved out a second identity as a collaborator and chronicler of rock history. He drummed for Queens of the Stone Age, formed supergroup Them Crooked Vultures, and directed the documentary Sound City, which explored analog recording culture and featured collaborations with artists across generations. His memoir, The Storyteller, further revealed a creative life marked by emotional candor, relentless curiosity, and a near-childlike joy in making noise with friends.

Through it all, Grohl managed the rare feat of being both ubiquitous and universally liked. Whether behind the kit, fronting a stadium crowd, or telling stories about the musicians who shaped him, he tends to project the same thing: a guy who still can’t believe he gets to do this for a living, and isn’t about to pretend otherwise.

Joseph Campbell (1904–1987) was an American writer, teacher, and comparative mythologist whose work reshaped modern understandings of narrative, religion, and the shared symbolic patterns running through world cultures. Born in White Plains, New York, Campbell discovered a lifelong fascination with myth at age seven after encountering stories of Native American peoples at the American Museum of Natural History. This early spark led him to study the world’s mythologies with an almost monastic intensity. He earned degrees from Columbia University, then spent several years in Europe absorbing the emerging fields of psychology, anthropology, and literature—reading James Joyce, studying medieval French, and diving into Jungian analysis. By the time he returned to the United States during the Great Depression, he had begun forging his own synthesis of these intellectual worlds.  

Campbell’s academic career took shape at Sarah Lawrence College, where he taught literature and comparative mythology for nearly four decades. His teaching blended philology, psychology, religious studies, and art history, but always returned to a central question: why do humans across cultures tell similar stories? This inquiry culminated in The Hero with a Thousand Faces (1949), the book in which Campbell introduced the “monomyth”—a universal hero’s journey pattern he argued appeared in myths across time and geography. Though debated by scholars, the framework resonated deeply with artists, writers, and filmmakers; it famously influenced George Lucas as he shaped Star Wars, and continues to inform popular storytelling to this day.  

Beyond academic circles, Campbell became a household name through The Power of Myth, a series of interviews conducted with journalist Bill Moyers and broadcast on PBS shortly after Campbell’s death. In those conversations, Campbell presented mythology not as dusty folklore but as a living guide to the human condition. He spoke about the role of ritual, the function of symbols, and the need for individuals to “follow their bliss”—a phrase that became a cultural touchstone, sometimes to his amusement and sometimes to his frustration, as people treated it like a self-help slogan rather than an existential directive.  

Campbell’s later writings expanded beyond hero myths to explore mythology’s relevance to modern life. In works such as Myths to Live By and the multi-volume The Masks of God, he argued that myth provides the metaphoric language through which societies understand themselves. He was also deeply engaged with Eastern religions—Hinduism, Buddhism, and Taoism—believing that Western culture had much to learn from their symbolic traditions. His synthesis of global mythologies helped popularize comparative religion at a time when the field was still taking shape in American academia.  

Though his legacy is not without controversy—critics have accused him of oversimplifying cultures, overly universalizing myths, or reading too much Jung into too many places—Campbell’s influence is vast and enduring. His ability to weave scholarship, storytelling, and philosophy into an accessible vision of human meaning made him one of the most widely read interpreters of myth in the 20th century. Today, Campbell stands not simply as a theorist of story, but as a bridge between ancient narratives and the modern search for purpose.

Harper Lee was born Nelle Harper Lee on April 28, 1926, in Monroeville, Alabama, a small Southern town that would later inspire the fictional Maycomb of To Kill a Mockingbird. The youngest of four children, she grew up in a household shaped by her father, Amasa Coleman Lee — a lawyer, newspaper editor, and state legislator whose moral seriousness and quiet integrity informed the character of Atticus Finch. Her childhood friendship with neighbor Truman Capote likewise left a lasting imprint on both writers’ imaginations.

After studying at Huntingdon College and the University of Alabama, Lee briefly attended law school but abandoned the degree to pursue writing in New York. Her big break came when a pair of friends gifted her a year’s worth of financial support so she could write full-time. The manuscript she produced — after significant editing with her editor, Tay Hohoff — became To Kill a Mockingbird (1960). The novel’s blend of Southern setting, racial injustice, and a child’s-eye moral awakening struck a nerve, earning the Pulitzer Prize and a permanent place in American literature.

The 1962 film adaptation, with Gregory Peck’s iconic performance as Atticus, amplified the book’s cultural reach and cemented Lee’s reputation. Yet she famously published no second novel for decades. Instead, she lived a largely private life, occasionally assisting Capote with research for In Cold Blood, granting few interviews, and maintaining a near-mythic distance from literary fame. Her silence became part of her mystique.

In 2015, Go Set a Watchman — an earlier draft related to Mockingbird — was published under controversial circumstances, raising questions about Lee’s consent and intention in her final years. Regardless, her legacy rests primarily on that original novel: a work taught, debated, banned, embraced, and continually reinterpreted across generations. Lee died in 2016 in her hometown of Monroeville, leaving behind a single, lightning-strike contribution that reshaped the American moral imagination.

Les Standiford, born in 1944 in Cambridge, Ohio, is an American novelist, historian, and writing professor known for blending meticulous research with a lively narrative voice. He grew up in the Midwest and later moved west, eventually earning an MFA from the University of Arizona. His early career included newspaper work, construction jobs, and a stint in Hollywood — experiences that shaped both his gritty realism and his interest in the machinery of storytelling.

Standiford is perhaps best known for his long-running John Deal crime series, which follows a Miami contractor entangled in criminal and political intrigue. The series helped establish him as a versatile writer capable of balancing suspense with fully realized characters and a strong sense of place. His fiction has been praised for its lean prose, moral complexity, and cinematic pacing.

Beyond crime fiction, Standiford made a substantial mark as a narrative historian. Books like Last Train to Paradise (about Henry Flagler and the building of the Florida East Coast Railway), Meet You in Hell (about Carnegie and Frick), and The Man Who Invented Christmas (about Dickens writing A Christmas Carol) showcased his ability to turn historical episodes into vivid, accessible storytelling. The Man Who Invented Christmas became a bestseller and inspired a feature film adaptation in 2017.

Standiford also helped shape the next generation of writers. As the founding director of the Creative Writing Program at Florida International University, he mentored dozens of authors who went on to successful careers. His influence as a teacher is often mentioned alongside his literary output — a testament to his generosity with both craft and encouragement.

He continues to write and teach, known for his eclectic interests, narrative clarity, and talent for finding the human pulse in both crime fiction and historical nonfiction.

Linwood Vrooman Carter (June 9, 1930 - February 7, 1988) was an American author of science fiction and fantasy, as well as an editor and critic. He usually wrote as Lin Carter; known pseudonyms include H.P. Lowcraft (for an H.P. Lovecraft parody) and Grail Undwin.

Carter was influential as a critic of contemporary fantasy and a pioneering historian of the genre. His book reviews and surveys of the year's best fantasy fiction appeared regularly in Castle of Frankenstein, continuing after that magazine's 1975 demise in The Year's Best Fantasy Stories. His early studies of the works of Tolkien (Tolkien: A Look Behind The Lord of the Rings) and H.P. Lovecraft (Lovecraft: A Look Behind the Cthulhu Mythos) were followed up by the wide-ranging Imaginary Worlds: The Art of Fantasy, a study tracing the emergence and development of modern fantasy from the late nineteenth century through the 1970s.

As an editor for Ballantine Books from 1969-1974, Carter brought several obscure yet important books of fantasy back into print under the Adult Fantasy line. He also helped new authors break into the field. Carter was a fantasy anthologist of note, editing a number of new anthologies of classic and contemporary fantasy for Ballantine and other publishers.

Together with Swordsmen and Sorcerers' Guild of America (SAGA) he sponsored the Gandalf Award, an early fantasy equivalent to science fiction's Hugo Award, for the recognization of outstanding merit in authors and works of fantasy. It was given annually by the World Science Fiction Society from 1974 to 1980. Its primary purpose continues to be fulfilled by the initially rival World Fantasy Awards, first presented in 1975.

Source: [Tolkien Gateway](https://tolkiengateway.net/wiki/Lin_Carter)

Richard L. Purtill (1931–2016) was an American philosopher, novelist, and scholar whose work bridged the worlds of analytic philosophy and imaginative literature. Born in Chicago, he developed early interests in storytelling and classical thought, which eventually led him to pursue philosophy at the graduate level. He earned his PhD from the University of Chicago and spent most of his academic career teaching philosophy at Western Washington University, where he became known as a clear, engaging lecturer with a deep interest in ethics, logic, and the philosophical underpinnings of myth.

Purtill wrote extensively on the relationship between fantasy literature and moral reasoning, carving out a niche as one of the early, serious scholars of C. S. Lewis, J. R. R. Tolkien, and the Inklings. His best-known nonfiction books — Lord of the Elves and Eldils, C. S. Lewis’ Case for the Christian Faith, and J. R. R. Tolkien: Myth, Morality, and Religion — examine how mythic storytelling expresses moral truths and metaphysical claims in ways that academic philosophy rarely can. His writing is marked by lucidity, balance, and a willingness to take literature’s spiritual dimensions seriously.

Alongside his scholarship, Purtill published several works of fantasy fiction, including the Kaphtu series, which blends mythic adventure with philosophical themes. These novels reflect his belief that stories do moral and intellectual work — that narrative can illuminate ethical questions more vividly than abstraction alone. His fiction never achieved bestseller status, but it earned a devoted readership among fans of mythic and classical fantasy.

Throughout his career Purtill maintained a reputation as a gentle, thoughtful scholar whose work invited readers to see fantasy literature not as escapism but as a mode of truth-telling. His combination of philosophical rigor and imaginative sympathy made him an important voice in Lewis and Tolkien studies during a period when such topics were still viewed skeptically in academia. Purtill died in 2016, leaving behind both scholarly and fictional contributions that continue to be appreciated by readers interested in the deeper meanings behind myth and fantasy.

John Gardner (1933-1982) was a noted American novelist, critic, and professor, famous for his 1971 novel Grendel, which retells the Beowulf epic from the monster's perspective, exploring themes of isolation, meaning, and morality, influenced by his own life's tragedy, particularly the accidental death of his younger brother. Gardner, a medieval literature scholar, crafted Grendel as a complex antihero, making the book a major work that blended academic insight with storytelling, solidifying his legacy before his own untimely death in a motorcycle accident.

Walt Whitman, born May 31, 1819, in West Hills, Long Island, grew up in a working-class family and received only a few years of formal schooling. Mostly self-taught, he worked as a printer’s apprentice, teacher, journalist, and editor — jobs that sharpened his ear for everyday American speech. Those experiences, along with his immersion in the bustling life of New York City, convinced him that poetry needed a new, democratic voice, one capable of capturing the energy and diversity of the young nation.

In 1855 he self-published the first edition of Leaves of Grass, a radically unconventional book of poems written in free verse, filled with sensuality, spiritual expansiveness, and a bold celebration of the self. Initially dismissed or condemned by critics, the book nevertheless caught the attention of Ralph Waldo Emerson, who saw in Whitman a poet who could carry forward the spirit of American transcendentalism. Whitman spent the rest of his life revising and expanding Leaves of Grass, treating it as a lifelong project rather than a single volume.

During the Civil War, Whitman volunteered as a nurse in Washington, D.C., tending to wounded soldiers in overcrowded hospitals. The experience profoundly affected him, infusing his later poetry with compassion, grief, and a renewed sense of the country’s shared humanity. Works like “Drum-Taps” and “When Lilacs Last in the Dooryard Bloom’d” reflect the emotional intensity of that period and his mourning for Abraham Lincoln, a figure he deeply admired.

Whitman’s later years were spent in Camden, New Jersey, where he continued writing, hosting visitors, and overseeing new editions of Leaves of Grass. Though often controversial for his open treatment of the body and sexuality, he gradually gained recognition as a major literary figure. By the time of his death in 1892, he had become widely regarded as the “good gray poet” — a national bard whose expansive, inclusive vision helped define American poetry.

Today, Whitman stands as a foundational figure in modern literature. His free verse, his democratic ethos, and his insistence on the sacredness of ordinary life continue to influence poets, novelists, and thinkers around the world. His voice remains unmistakably his own: exuberant, intimate, and endlessly searching.

Stephen Edwin King was born September 21, 1947, in Portland, Maine. His father abandoned the family when Stephen was just two, leaving his mother to raise him and his brother under often difficult financial circumstances. As a child, King was an avid reader of horror comics and science fiction magazines, and by the time he reached high school he was already writing short stories — many of them sold to classmates for pocket change until a teacher shut the enterprise down.

King attended the University of Maine, where he wrote for the student newspaper and met Tabitha Spruce, whom he married in 1971. After graduation, he struggled to make ends meet, working as a laborer and later as a high school English teacher while writing in the evenings. His breakthrough came with Carrie (1974). Legend has it that Tabitha rescued the first pages from the trash, encouraged him to finish, and the resulting novel launched one of the most astounding careers in American popular literature.

Over the following decades, King published a torrent of bestselling novels and stories — ’Salem’s Lot, The Shining, The Stand, It, Misery, Pet Sematary, The Dark Tower cycle, and dozens more. His ability to blend horror, suspense, psychological insight, and Americana made him both a cultural phenomenon and a defining voice in modern storytelling. Film and television adaptations multiplied, shaping the popular imagination for generations. His writing is marked not just by scares, but by empathy for ordinary people pushed into extraordinary circumstances.

King’s personal life has included its own dramatic turns. In 1999 he survived a near-fatal accident when a van struck him during a walk; the long recovery shaped later works and deepened themes of mortality and resilience. He has also been open about his earlier struggles with alcoholism and addiction, crediting his family with helping him rebuild his life and career.

Stephen King remains very much alive and active, continuing to publish novels, essays, screenplays, and short stories well into his seventies. With more than 60 novels, hundreds of short stories, and global sales in the hundreds of millions, he stands as one of the most influential storytellers of the last century — a writer who turned horror into a vehicle for exploring the fears, hopes, and hidden corners of American life.

### Biography  
Robin Jensen’s interdisciplinary research and publications focus on the relationship between early Christian art and literature to explore the ways that visual images and architectural spaces are modes of theological expression and reflect the nature and content of devotional piety and explicate ritual practices. She teaches courses on the character of late antique Christian and Jewish art, the history and evolution of Christian architecture, the iconography of the cross and crucifix, depictions of Christ and the Virgin Mary, and the place and controversies over images and idols in ancient and early medieval Christianity. Additionally, she has researched the practices, distinctive character, and material evidence of Christianity in Roman North Africa.

### Research Interests  
History of Christian Art, History of Christian Architecture, History of Christianity in Roman Africa, Initiation and Early Christian Baptism, Theology of Sacred Images in Eastern and Western Christian Tradition, Liturgical Theology

### Selected Publications  
Understanding Early Christian Art: Revised Edition (a significantly updated and revised edition of the 2000 version of this title). London: Routledge, 2023.

From Idols to Icons: The Emergence of Christian Devotional Images in Late Antiquity (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2022).

The Cross: History, Art, and Controversy (Cambridge. MA: Harvard University Press, 2017).

Christianity in Roman Africa: The Development of its Practices and Beliefs, with J. Patout Burns (Grand Rapids: Eerdmans, 2014).
Winner, 2015 Catholic Press Association Book Award (History).

Baptismal Imagery in Early Christianity (Grand Rapids: Baker Academic, 2012).
Second place, 2013 Catholic Press Association Book Award (Liturgy).

Education
Ph.D., M.A., Columbia University, NY
B.A., Concordia College, Moorhead, MN

Albert Camus (1913-1960) was a French-Algerian philosopher, author, and journalist, known for his contributions to absurdism, opposing nihilism, and winning the 1957 Nobel Prize in Literature for works like The Stranger and The Plague. Born in poverty in Algeria, he excelled in philosophy at the University of Algiers before moving to France, where he became a key figure in the Resistance and Combat newspaper, advocating justice and freedom, and later famously split with Sartre over political ideologies. He died in a car crash in 1960, leaving behind a legacy of powerful fiction and essays exploring human existence, rebellion, and meaning.

Samuel Taylor Coleridge, a leader of the British Romantic movement, was born on October 21, 1772, in Devonshire, England. His father, a vicar of a parish and master of a grammar school, married twice and had fourteen children. The youngest child in the family, Coleridge was a student at his father’s school and an avid reader. After his father died in 1781, Coleridge attended Christ’s Hospital School in London, where he met lifelong friend Charles Lamb. While in London, he also befriended a classmate named Tom Evans, who introduced Coleridge to his family. Coleridge fell in love with Tom’s older sister, Mary.

Coleridge’s father had always wanted his son to be a clergyman, so when Coleridge entered Jesus College, University of Cambridge in 1791, he focused on a future in the Church of England.
